Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I was finishing up my shift at the construction site, sweat clinging to my back under the afternoon sun. My mind was already drifting to the family ceremony tonight—my mother had called twice to remind me not to be late, to come home clean and dressed in my best kurta. As I walked toward the gate, I spotted a small puddle of oil glistening on the walkway, right where the next crew would be coming through. The safety officer’s words echoed in my head: “We all have to look out for each other. Even small spills can cause big accidents.” I knew I should grab the mop and clean it up, but my watch told me I was already cutting it close. If I stopped now, I’d be late, and my family would be disappointed. If I left, someone could get hurt, and I’d be failing my responsibility to my coworkers. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between duty to my job and devotion to my family and faith, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
